elements.content: Novel Eu­(III) coordination polymers with furan-based bridging ligands [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n and [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n (hfa: hexafluoroacetylacetonato, Cy: 2,5-bis­(dicyclohexylphosphoryl)­furan), Tol: 2,5-bis­(di-p-tolylphosphoryl)­furan) are reported. The rigidity of assembly steric structures was controlled by intermolecular interactions through the side groups in bridging ligands. They exhibited one of the best performances (thermal stability above 320 °C and external photoluminescence quantum yields of up to 71%) among reported lanthanide­(III) compounds. The triboluminescence activity was demonstrated to be dependent on the mechanical stability of the coordination polymers, which was proportional to the number of hydrogen atoms in the side groups. The second example of a large TL/PL spectral difference in [Tb,Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n also revealed discrete photophysical processes under the conditions of grinding and UV irradiation.

They exhibited one of the best performances (thermal stability above 320 °C and external photoluminescence quantum yields of up to 71%) among reported lanthanide(III) compounds. The triboluminescence activity was demonstrated to be dependent on the mechanical stability of the coordination polymers, which was proportional to the number of hydrogen atoms in the side groups. The second example of a large TL/PL spectral difference in [Tb,Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n  also revealed discrete photophysical processes under the conditions of grinding and UV irradiation.

elements.content: Assembly of steric structures of lanthanide­(III) coordination polymers were successfully controlled by the number of hydrogen atoms in the side groups of furan-based bridging ligands, and strong photoluminescence (PL), thermal stability, and unique triboluminescence (TL) were observed. The physical properties were significantly affected by intermolecular packing structures, and the second example of large TL/PL spectral difference was also found and discussed on the basis of photophysical parameters.

elements.content: Control of the molecular conformation and assembly steric structure is important to enhance mechanical, thermodynamic, and photophysical properties of chemical compounds. Johnson and co-workers controlled the mechanical stability of gels by increasing the number of cross-linking points using Pd­(II)-based coordination systems. Du et al. succeeded in synthesizing helical Eu­(III)-carboxylate networks with thermal stability up to 450 °C. Kawai et al. also demonstrated on/off switchable circularly polarized luminescence of a tetrathiazole driven by intermolecular conformation change. These works have provided an insight into the structure–property correlation of assembled systems as well as the potential for advanced functional materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Control of the molecular conformation and assembly steric structure is important to enhance mechanical, thermodynamic, and photophysical properties of chemical compounds. Johnson and co-workers controlled the mechanical stability of gels by increasing the number of cross-linking points using Pd(II)-based coordination systems. Du et al. succeeded in synthesizing helical Eu(III)-carboxylate networks with thermal stability up to 450 °C. Kawai et al. also demonstrated on/off switchable circularly polarized luminescence of a tetrathiazole driven by intermolecular conformation change. These works have provided an insight into the structure-property correlation of assembled systems as well as the potential for advanced functional materials.

elements.content: Particularly well-known is triboluminescence (TL), which is strongly related to assembly steric structures in a solid state. TL is observed when crystalline organic, inorganic, and coordination compounds are mechanically stimulated, and these compounds are attractive candidates for structural damage sensors and security marking techniques. Since the first official record of sugar glow was made in 1605, detailed spectroscopic and crystallographic characterization of existing TL materials has been reported. Many photoluminscence (PL) compounds have also been found to show TL, and the underlying mechanisms have been discussed on the basis of the spectral profiles; however, studies focusing on the control of TL properties by novel and systematic molecular designs are still in their early stage. A simple molecular strategy that induces drastic change in TL properties is required to provide a key to structure–property correlation.

elements.content: In this regard, lanthanide­(III) (Ln­(III))-hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfa) coordination polymers are attractive candidates because of their bright TL as represented by [Eu­(hfa)3(X)] n (X = 3,3′-bis­(diphenylphosphoryl)-2,2′-bipyridine (bipypo), 1,4-diacetylbenzene (acbz), or 1,4-diacetoxybenzene (acetbz)). The strong, sharp, and long-lived 4f–4f emission in Ln­(III) ions is clearly recognizable compared to the discharge spectra of surrounding gases in organic compounds or the metal–metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MMLCT) in d-block transition metal complexes. The strong PL properties due to the photosensitization effects also help us to understand the TL mechanisms from the photophysical basis. Our group also recently found that the Ln­(III)-hfa coordination polymers with an intermolecular face-to-face arrangement of −CF3 groups exhibited strong TL and PL, while highly ordered alternative arrangements lowered the TL activity. Therefore, the control of intermolecular structures would significantly affect the TL property of Ln­(III) coordination polymers. The TL/PL color difference is also a unique and attractive feature of Ln­(III)-mixed coordination polymers under the condition in which there are discrete photophysical processes.

elements.content: In this study, we simply focused on the side groups of Ln­(III)-hfa coordination polymers with furan-derivative bridging ligands to investigate the relationships between TL/PL properties and intermolecular structures (). Because of the small π-aromatic surface and large bite angle, the furyl core would not undergo CH−π interactions with hydrogen atoms in neighboring polymer chains unlike biphenyl-, carbazole-, and bithiophene-bridged Eu­(III) coordination polymers with rigid structures. Thus, the structure-based properties of furan-bridged Ln­(III) coordination polymers including TL activity, thermodynamic stability, and PL efficiency are expected to be dependent on the intermolecular hfa/side group (CH–F) and/or side group/side group (π–π, CH−π) interactions.

Thus, the structure-based properties of furan-bridged Ln(III) coordination polymers including TL activity, thermodynamic stability, and PL efficiency are expected to be dependent on the intermolecular hfa/side group (CH-F) and/or side group/side group (π-π, CH-π) interactions.

elements.content: Novel furan-based bridging ligands with cyclohexyl and tolyl side groups (2,5-bis­(dicyclohexylphosphoryl)­furan: Cy and 2,5-bis­(di-p-tolylphosphoryl)­furan: Tol) were synthesized starting from 2,5-dibromofuran (see ). A phenylene-substituted ligand (2,5-bis­(diphenylphosphoryl)­furan: Ph) was also prepared to compare the properties. The intermolecular interactions were systematically controlled according to the number of hydrogen atoms in each side group (11: Cy, 7: Tol, and 5: Ph). The structural features of Eu­(III) coordination polymers were characterized by single-crystal X-ray analyses and thermogravimetric analyses. The structure–property correlations were investigated on the basis of TL/PL spectroscopy. A large TL/PL spectral difference was demonstrated in Tb­(III)/Eu­(III)-mixed systems with Tol bridges, and the key structures and photophysical processes for TL are discussed. The proposed “side-group alteration” strategy also provides an important concept of molecular designs to develop a series of Ln­(III)-based high-performance optical materials.

Experimental SectionMaterials

Europium acetate n-hydrate (99.9%), terbium acetate tetrahydrate (99.9%), 1.55 M n-butyllithium (n-BuLi) in n-hexane, and hydrogen peroxide were purchased from Kanto Chemical Co., Inc. 2,5-Dibromofuran, chlorodicylohexylpohsphine (P­(Cy)2Cl), chlorodi­(p-tolyl)­phosphine (P­(p-Tol)2Cl), and chlorodiphenylphosphine (PPh2Cl) were obtained from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. All other chemicals and solvents were reagent-grade and were used without further purification.

elements.content: 1H NMR (400 MHz) spectra were recorded on a JEOL ECS400. Chemical shifts were reported in δ ppm, referenced to an internal tetramethylsilane standard for 1H NMR spectroscopy. Infrared spectra were recorded on a JASCO FTIR-420 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Elemental analyses were performed by an Exeter Analytical CE440. elements.content: In a degassed three-necked round-bottomed flask (300 mL), 2,5-dibromofuran (0.65 mL, 5.8 mmol) was dissolved in dry THF (60 mL) under argon atmosphere, then stirred until a homogeneous solution was formed at room temperature. A solution of n-BuLi (8.3 mL, 13 mmol) was added dropwise to the solution at −80 °C. The addition was completed in ca. 15 min. The mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h, after which P­(Cy)2Cl (2.8 mL, 13 mmol) was added dropwise at −80 °C and the solution became cloudy. The mixture was gradually brought to room temperature and stirred for 14 h to form a clouded yellow solution. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvent was concentrated and dissolved in dichloromethane (100 mL) in a flask. The solution was cooled to 0 °C and then 30% H2O2 aqueous solution (6.0 mL) was added to it. The reaction mixture was stirred for 3 h. The product was extracted with dichloromethane, and the obtained crude powder was washed with ethyl acetate several times to afford white powder. Yield: 1.7 g (59%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD, 25 °C) δ 7.30 (s, 2H, −CH), δ 2.02–2.22 (m, 8H, −CH2), δ 1.61–1.86 (m, 16H, −CH2), δ 1.10–1.42 (m, 20H, −CH2) ppm. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C28H47O3P2 [M + H]+, 493.29; found, 493.30. Anal. Calcd for C28H46O3P2: C, 68.27; H, 9.41%. Found: C, 67.77; H, 9.33%.

In a degassed three-necked round-bottomed flask (300 mL), 2,5-dibromofuran (0.65 mL, 5.8 mmol) was dissolved in dry THF (60 mL) under argon atmosphere, then stirred until a homogeneous solution was formed at room temperature. A solution of n-BuLi (8.3 mL, 13 mmol) was added dropwise to the solution at -80 °C. The addition was completed in ca. 15 min. The mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h, after which P(Cy)2Cl (2.8 mL, 13 mmol) was added dropwise at -80 °C and the solution became cloudy. The mixture was gradually brought to room temperature and stirred for 14 h to form a clouded yellow solution. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvent was concentrated and dissolved in dichloromethane (100 mL) in a flask. The solution was cooled to 0 °C and then 30% H2O2 aqueous solution (6.0 mL) was added to it. The reaction mixture was stirred for 3 h. The product was extracted with dichloromethane, and the obtained crude powder was washed with ethyl acetate several times to afford white powder. Yield: 1.7 g (59%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD, 25 °C) δ 7.30 (s, 2H, -CH), δ 2.02-2.22 (m, 8H, -CH2), δ 1.61-1.86 (m, 16H, -CH2), δ 1.10-1.42 (m, 20H, -CH2) ppm. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C28H47O3P2 [M + H]+, 493.29; found, 493.30. Anal. Calcd for C28H46O3P2: C, 68.27; H, 9.41%. Found: C, 67.77; H, 9.33%.

A solution of n-BuLi (13 mL, 21 mmol) was added dropwise to the solution at −80 °C. The addition was completed in ca. 15 min. The mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h, after which P­(p-Tol)2Cl (4.4 mL, 20 mmol) was added dropwise at −80 °C and the solution became cloudy. The mixture was gradually brought to room temperature and stirred for 14 h to form a clouded yellow solution. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvent was concentrated and dissolved in dichloromethane (40 mL) in a flask. The solution was cooled to 0 °C, and 30% H2O2 aqueous solution (8.0 mL) was added to it. The reaction mixture was stirred for 3 h. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and the obtained crude powder was washed with ethyl acetate for several times to afford a white powder. Preparation of 2,5-Bis(di-p-tolylphosphoryl)furan (Tol)

In a degassed three-necked round-bottomed flask (300 mL), 2,5-dibromofuran (1.0 mL, 9.3 mmol) was dissolved in dry THF (60 mL) under argon atmosphere, then stirred until a homogeneous solution was formed at room temperature. A solution of n-BuLi (13 mL, 21 mmol) was added dropwise to the solution at -80 °C. The addition was completed in ca. 15 min. The mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h, after which P(p-Tol)2Cl (4.4 mL, 20 mmol) was added dropwise at -80 °C and the solution became cloudy. The mixture was gradually brought to room temperature and stirred for 14 h to form a clouded yellow solution. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvent was concentrated and dissolved in dichloromethane (40 mL) in a flask. The solution was cooled to 0 °C, and 30% H2O2 aqueous solution (8.0 mL) was added to it. The reaction mixture was stirred for 3 h. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and the obtained crude powder was washed with ethyl acetate for several times to afford a white powder. Yield: 3.0 g (61%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD, 25 °C) δ 7.44-7.49 (m, 8H, -CH), δ 7.31-7.33 (m, 8H, -CH), δ 7.17 (t, 2H, -CH), δ 2.41 (s, 12H, -CH3) ppm. Preparation of [Eu(hfa)3(Cy)] n  

Phosphine oxide ligand Cy (0.80 mmol) and Eu(hfa)3(H2O)2 (0.80 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (60 mL), respectively. The solutions were mixed and refluxed for 3 h to form white precipitates. The obtained white solid was washed with methanol. Yield: 0.54 g (53% for monomer). IR (KBr): 2854-2931 (m, C-H), 1656 (st, CO), 1139 (st, PO) cm-1. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C38H48EuF12O7P2 [M - hfa]+: 1059.2, found, 1059.3. Anal. Calcd for C43H49EuF18O9P2: C, 40.80; H, 3.90%. Found: C, 40.84; H, 3.84%.

elements.content: Phosphine oxide ligand Tol (0.80 mmol) and Ln­(hfa)3(H2O)2 (0.80 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (60 mL), respectively. The solutions were mixed and refluxed for 3 h. The reaction mixture was concentrated and washed with chloroform. The solvent was evaporated and redissolved in 50 °C methanol for recrystallization. The obtained crystals were washed with −20 °C methanol.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Ln(hfa)3(Tol)] n  (Ln = Eu, Tb, or Mixture Thereof)

Phosphine oxide ligand Tol (0.80 mmol) and Ln(hfa)3(H2O)2 (0.80 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (60 mL), respectively. The solutions were mixed and refluxed for 3 h. The reaction mixture was concentrated and washed with chloroform. The solvent was evaporated and redissolved in 50 °C methanol for recrystallization. The obtained crystals were washed with -20 °C methanol.

elements.content: The coordination structures were determined using single crystal X-ray analyses. The single crystals were obtained by liquid–liquid diffusion for [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n , and slow evaporation for [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n . The Eu­(hfa)3(H2O)2/methanol solution was added on the layer of Cy ligand/CH2Cl2 solution, and the slow diffusion of these solutions resulted in forming crystals of [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n . The 50 °C methanol solution of [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n was held at room temperature, and the slow evaporation resulted in forming crystals of [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The coordination structures were determined using single crystal X-ray analyses. The single crystals were obtained by liquid-liquid diffusion for [Eu(hfa)3(Cy)] n , and slow evaporation for [Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n . The Eu(hfa)3(H2O)2/methanol solution was added on the layer of Cy ligand/CH2Cl2 solution, and the slow diffusion of these solutions resulted in forming crystals of [Eu(hfa)3(Cy)] n . The 50 °C methanol solution of [Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n  was held at room temperature, and the slow evaporation resulted in forming crystals of [Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n .

elements.content: The colorless single crystals were mounted on a MiTiGen micromesh using Paratone-N. The measurements were performed on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were refined using the riding model. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package. CIF data was confirmed by using the checkCIF/PLATON service. The crystallographic parameters are summarized in Table S7, and CCDC 1857380 for [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n and CCDC 1857381 for [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

elements.content: In order to investigate the geometrical symmetry around the EuIII ions, the degree of distortion against an 8-coordinated square-antiprismatic structure (8-SAP, point group: D 4d ) and an 8-coordinated trigonal-dodecahedral structure (8-TDH, point group, D 2d ) was evaluated on the basis of shape factor S: S = min ⁡ ( 1 m ) ∑ i = 1 m ( δ i − θ i ) 2 ··· where m, δ i , and θ i are the number of possible edges (m = 18 in this study), the observed dihedral angle between planes along the ith edge and the dihedral angle for the ideal structure, respectively. The observed dihedral angles (δ i ), idealized dihedral angles for a square antiprism (θSAP), and a trigonal dodecahedron (θTDH), calculated measure shape criteria, S SAP and S TDH, are summarized in Figures S1 and S2 and Tables S1 and S2. The estimated values of S TDH are smaller than those of S SAP for both [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n (S SAP = 8.77 > S TDH = 7.69) and [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n (S SAP = 12.3 > S TDH = 11.0), indicating that the coordination geometry is categorized as 8-TDH.

elements.content: UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a JASCO V-670 spectrometer. Emission and excitation spectra were recorded on a HORIBA Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorometer and corrected for the response of the detector system. Emission lifetimes (τobs) were measured using the third harmonics (355 nm) of a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser (Spectra Physiscs, INDI-50, fwhm = 5 ns, λ = 1064 nm) and a photomultiplier (Hamamatsu photonics, R5108, response time ≤ 1.1 ns). The Nd:YAG laser response was monitored with a digital oscilloscope (Sony Tektronix, TDS3052, 500 MHz) synchronized to the single-pulse excitation. Emission lifetimes were determined from the slope of logarithmic plots of the decay profiles. The emission quantum yields excited at 380 nm (Φtot) were estimated using JASCO F-6300-H spectrometer attached with JASCO ILF-533 integrating sphere unit (φ = 100 mm). The wavelength dependence of the detector response and the beam intensity of Xe light source for each spectrum were calibrated using a standard light source. The emission quantum yields excited by Eu­(III) ions (Φff) were calculated using the following equations. Φ ff = k r k r + k nr = τ obs τ rad ··· k r = 1 τ rad = A MD , 0 n 3 ( I tot I MD ) ··· k nr = 1 τ obs − 1 τ rad ··· A MD,0 is the spontaneous emission probability for 5D0–7F1 transition in vacuo (14.65 s–1), n is the refractive index of the medium (an average index of refraction equal to 1.5 was used), and I tot/I MD is the ratio of the total area of the corrected EuIII emission spectrum to the area of the 5D0–7F1 band. The TL/PL spectral measurements were performed on a Photonic Hamamatsu PMA-12 Multichannel Analyzer.

UV-vis absorption spectra were recorded on a JASCO V-670 spectrometer. Emission and excitation spectra were recorded on a HORIBA Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorometer and corrected for the response of the detector system. Emission lifetimes (τobs) were measured using the third harmonics (355 nm) of a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser (Spectra Physiscs, INDI-50, fwhm = 5 ns, λ = 1064 nm) and a photomultiplier (Hamamatsu photonics, R5108, response time ≤ 1.1 ns). The Nd:YAG laser response was monitored with a digital oscilloscope (Sony Tektronix, TDS3052, 500 MHz) synchronized to the single-pulse excitation. Emission lifetimes were determined from the slope of logarithmic plots of the decay profiles. The emission quantum yields excited at 380 nm (Φtot) were estimated using JASCO F-6300-H spectrometer attached with JASCO ILF-533 integrating sphere unit (φ = 100 mm). The wavelength dependence of the detector response and the beam intensity of Xe light source for each spectrum were calibrated using a standard light source. The emission quantum yields excited by Eu(III) ions (Φff) were calculated using the following equations.       Φ   ff   =     k   r       k   r   +   k   nr     =     τ   obs       τ   rad     ⋅⋅⋅   2        k   r   =   1     τ   rad     =   A   MD , 0     n   3    (     I   tot       I   MD     )  ⋅⋅⋅   3        k   nr   =   1     τ   obs     -   1     τ   rad     ⋅⋅⋅   4  A MD,0 is the spontaneous emission probability for 5D0-7F1 transition in vacuo (14.65 s-1), n is the refractive index of the medium (an average index of refraction equal to 1.5 was used), and I tot/I MD is the ratio of the total area of the corrected EuIII emission spectrum to the area of the 5D0-7F1 band. elements.content: As Ln­(III) TL involves the same excited state as PL, the TL efficiency is affected by the intrinsic emission quantum yields (Φff) and then the coordination structures around Ln­(III) ions. In order to investigate the coordination structures of Eu­(III) coordination polymers, single crystal X-ray analyses were performed. All of the compounds formed polymeric one-dimensional chains with an Eu­(III) ion, three hfa ligands, and a bridging ligand per unit cells. On the basis of the X-ray data obtained, we calculated the shape factor S to estimate the degree of distortion of the first coordination sphere around Eu­(III) ions (see Figures S1 and S2 and Tables S1 and S2). [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n and [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n were categorized as an 8-coordinated trigonal-dodecahedral structure (8-TDH, point group: D 4d ), rather than a square-antiprismatic structure (8-SAP, point group: D 2d ) that was reported for [Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n . The f–f hypersensitive transitions intensity generally depends on the point group symmetry around Ln­(III) ions and their excited states are nonradiatively quenched through vibrational relaxation. Then the asymmetric and low-vibrational coordination structures surrounded by β-diketonate and phosphine oxide ligands may induce efficient Ln­(III)-centered emission.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

As Ln(III) TL involves the same excited state as PL, the TL efficiency is affected by the intrinsic emission quantum yields (Φff) and then the coordination structures around Ln(III) ions. In order to investigate the coordination structures of Eu(III) coordination polymers, single crystal X-ray analyses were performed. All of the compounds formed polymeric one-dimensional chains with an Eu(III) ion, three hfa ligands, and a bridging ligand per unit cells. On the basis of the X-ray data obtained, we calculated the shape factor S  to estimate the degree of distortion of the first coordination sphere around Eu(III) ions (see Figures S1 and S2 and Tables S1 and S2). [Eu(hfa)3(Cy)] n  and [Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n  were categorized as an 8-coordinated trigonal-dodecahedral structure (8-TDH, point group: D 4d ), rather than a square-antiprismatic structure (8-SAP, point group: D 2d ) that was reported for [Eu(hfa)3(Ph)] n . The f-f hypersensitive transitions intensity generally depends on the point group symmetry around Ln(III) ions and their excited states are nonradiatively quenched through vibrational relaxation. Then the asymmetric and low-vibrational coordination structures surrounded by β-diketonate and phosphine oxide ligands may induce efficient Ln(III)-centered emission.

elements.content: Since TL is a fracture-induced phenomenon, the excitation probability is also strongly related to the packing structures of the molecules. We next focused on the intermolecular interactions between single polymer chains. Multiple intermolecular CH–F hydrogen bonds were observed for [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n between the cyclohexyl groups in Cy ligands and fluorine atoms in hfa ligands (a and Tables S3). This type of highly zipped structure is assumed to be mechanically and thermodynamically stable, which would result in quite low TL activity. For [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n , the hydrogen atoms in tolyl groups and fluorine atoms in hfa ligands formed CH–F hydrogen bonds (b and Table S4). Although the number of intermolecular CH–F contacts within 3.0 Å was much smaller for [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n (12 contacts) than for [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n (22 contacts), the head-to-tail arrangement of tolyl groups provided intermolecular π–π and CH−π interactions (d π–π = 3.667 Å and d CH−π = 2.890 Å) that were not identified in [Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n . Considering the binding energies of CH–F and CH−π hydrogen bonds (10–30 and 2–10 kJ mol–1, respectively), the mechanical stability of these compounds was assumed to be [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n > [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n > [Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n .

For [Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n , the hydrogen atoms in tolyl groups and fluorine atoms in hfa ligands formed CH-F hydrogen bonds (b and Table S4). Although the number of intermolecular CH-F contacts within 3.0 Å was much smaller for [Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n  (12 contacts) than for [Eu(hfa)3(Cy)] n  (22 contacts), the head-to-tail arrangement of tolyl groups provided intermolecular π-π and CH-π interactions (d π-π = 3.667 Å and d CH-π = 2.890 Å) that were not identified in [Eu(hfa)3(Ph)] n . elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were also conducted to examine the thermodynamic stability of polymer chains. The decomposition points were estimated to be 334, 320, and 267 °C for [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n , [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n , and [Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n , respectively (). The remarkably high thermal stability of [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n is due to the strong interactions through multiple intra- and intermolecular CH–F hydrogen bonds. The intramolecular CH–F and CH−π interactions in [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n also allowed the polymer chains to be stable at temperatures above 300 °C, which was similar to the thermally stable helical EuIII coordination polymer with multiple intramolecular hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: TL measurements of Eu­(III) coordination polymers revealed that the TL activity was inversely proportional to the mechanical stability (a–c). [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n exhibited TL despite its thermal stability and a nonchiral space group (P1̅), which explains why the intermolecular structure is a dominant factor for TL activity. The existence of face-to-face arranged −CF3 groups (see Figure S3) was also related to the TL activity of [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n and [Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n , since these molecular configurations could prevent the formation of strong hydrogen bonds between polymer chains.

elements.content: Sweeting and Rheingold reported that the disorder of organic ligands in an Eu­(III) complex provided a sufficient source for the development of a voltage across the growing crack to excite Eu­(III) ions in a centrosymmetric space group. The same group also suggested that the weak interactions in the molecules caused the creation of polar domains that resulted in TL activity even without significant disorders. According to the average thermal displacement parameters (U eq) of fluorine atoms ([Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n : 0.15 Å2, [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n : 0.27 Å2, [Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n : 0.07 Å2), no significant anisotropic disorders were identified. Therefore, the weaker intermolecular interactions and −CF3 arrangements would be key factors to produce fractures that trigger TL in these systems.

According to the average thermal displacement parameters (U eq) of fluorine atoms ([Eu(hfa)3(Cy)] n : 0.15 Å2, [Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n : 0.27 Å2, [Eu(hfa)3(Ph)] n : 0.07 Å2), no significant anisotropic disorders were identified. Therefore, the weaker intermolecular interactions and -CF3 arrangements would be key factors to produce fractures that trigger TL in these systems.

elements.content: All of the compounds also exhibited strong Eu­(III)-centered PL (d–f), and the PL parameters were calculated (see –) and summarized in . The large radiative rate constants (k r > 9.0 × 102 s–1) were due to the asymmetric coordination geometry around Eu­(III) ions and the polar character of furan-based bridging ligands that induced an increase of 4f–4f transition probability. The multiple intra- and intermolecular CH–F hydrogen bonds significantly lowered the nonradiative rate constant (k nr) of [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n (k nr = 95 s–1) by forming a low-vibrational coordination structure. The CH–F, π–π, and CH−π interactions in [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n also suppressed the molecular vibration to show a 45% smaller k nr value than that of [Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n . The highest mechanical stability of [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n contributed to the largest intrinsic PL quantum yield (Φff = 91%), which resulted in the lowest fracture probability and TL-silent property as well. The PL efficiency therefore had little relevance to TL intensity. Teotonio and co-workers reported that the photosensitization effect in Eu­(III) complexes did not necessarily induce strong TL and that the crystal structural features might play a role in TL activity.

Ref .

For further understanding of TL/PL properties, Tb­(III)/Eu­(III)-mixed coordination polymers [Tb,Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n (Tb/Eu = 1, 10) were prepared, and TL/PL spectra were recorded using a CCD system (see Figure S4). The PL parameters and TL properties of [Ln­(hfa)3(X)] n (Ln = Eu, Tb, or mixture thereof, X = Tol or Ph) were summarized in Table S6. Although the recorded TL spectra had poor signal-to-noise ratio due to the relatively low TL activity (), they were obviously not identical to those of PL, being the second example of emission color difference under the condition of grinding and UV irradiation. The TL/PL colors were evaluated based on CIE 1931 chromaticity coordinates, and their differences in [Tb,Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n were found to be smaller than those in [Tb,Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n (; see Table S6 for emission intensity ratio). Since the ligand-excited quantum yields (Φtot) were almost the same within experimental errors for [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n /[Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n and [Tb­(hfa)3(Tol)] n /[Tb­(hfa)3(Ph)] n , they would not rationalize the degree of TL/PL color difference. The intrinsic quantum yields (Φff) seemed rather important than Φtot for TL color determination, and the smaller TL/PL color difference in [Ln­(hfa)3(Tol)] n were probably due to the same Φff of [Ln­(hfa)3(Tol)] n (Φff,Eu = Φff,Tb = 82%), while there was a 15% difference in [Ln­(hfa)3(Ph)] n (Φff,Eu = 73, Φff,Tb = 88%). The identical TL/PL profiles of [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n and [Tb­(hfa)3(Tol)] n (see Figure S5) also indicated that the TL involved the same Ln­(III) excited states as PL (5D0 for Eu­(III) and 5D4 for Tb­(III) ions, respectively). These features are consistent with our previous claim that TL and PL have discrete photophysical processes and that TL is dominated by direct-Ln­(III) excitation rather than ligand excitation.

elements.content: In conclusion, the TL activity of strong PL furan-bridged Ln­(III) coordination polymers was systematically controlled by side group alteration. The hydrogen atoms in the side groups remarkably affected the mechanical, thermodynamic, and photophysical properties of assembled structures in a solid state. The highly stable and TL-silent [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n achieved one of the best performances (external PL efficiency: 71%, thermal stability: 334 °C) among reported Ln­(III) coordination compounds. [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n also exhibited strong PL with high thermal stability, and TL was observed due to the relatively weak intermolecular interactions and characteristic −CF3 arrangements. The second example of a large TL/PL spectral difference in [Tb,Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n revealed discrete photophysical processes and a probable role of intrinsic quantum yields in TL color determination. The quantitative TL measurements would make it possible to estimate the photophysical parameters for transition efficiencies and excited state dynamics that are related to emission colors.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, the TL activity of strong PL furan-bridged Ln(III) coordination polymers was systematically controlled by side group alteration. The hydrogen atoms in the side groups remarkably affected the mechanical, thermodynamic, and photophysical properties of assembled structures in a solid state. The highly stable and TL-silent [Eu(hfa)3(Cy)] n  achieved one of the best performances (external PL efficiency: 71%, thermal stability: 334 °C) among reported Ln(III) coordination compounds. [Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n  also exhibited strong PL with high thermal stability, and TL was observed due to the relatively weak intermolecular interactions and characteristic -CF3 arrangements. The second example of a large TL/PL spectral difference in [Tb,Eu(hfa)3(Tol)] n  revealed discrete photophysical processes and a probable role of intrinsic quantum yields in TL color determination. The quantitative TL measurements would make it possible to estimate the photophysical parameters for transition efficiencies and excited state dynamics that are related to emission colors.

cln_elements.content:
In a degassed three-necked round-bottomed flask (300 mL), 2,5-dibromofuran (0.65 mL, 5.8 mmol) was dissolved in dry THF (60 mL) under argon atmosphere, then stirred until a homogeneous solution was formed at room temperature. A solution of n-BuLi (8.3 mL, 13 mmol) was added dropwise to the solution at −80 °C. The addition was completed in ca. 15 min. The mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h, after which P­(Cy)2Cl (2.8 mL, 13 mmol) was added dropwise at −80 °C and the solution became cloudy. The mixture was gradually brought to room temperature and stirred for 14 h to form a clouded yellow solution. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvent was concentrated and dissolved in dichloromethane (100 mL) in a flask. The solution was cooled to 0 °C and then 30% H2O2 aqueous solution (6.0 mL) was added to it. The reaction mixture was stirred for 3 h. The product was extracted with dichloromethane, and the obtained crude powder was washed with ethyl acetate several times to afford white powder. Yield: 1.7 g (59%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD, 25 °C) δ 7.30 (s, 2H, −CH), δ 2.02–2.22 (m, 8H, −CH2), δ 1.61–1.86 (m, 16H, −CH2), δ 1.10–1.42 (m, 20H, −CH2) ppm. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C28H47O3P2 [M + H]+, 493.29; found, 493.30. Anal. Calcd for C28H46O3P2: C, 68.27; H, 9.41%. Found: C, 67.77; H, 9.33%.

Preparation of 2,5-Bis­(di-<italic>p</italic>-tolylphosphoryl)­furan (Tol)

In a degassed three-necked round-bottomed flask (300 mL), 2,5-dibromofuran (1.0 mL, 9.3 mmol) was dissolved in dry THF (60 mL) under argon atmosphere, then stirred until a homogeneous solution was formed at room temperature. A solution of n-BuLi (13 mL, 21 mmol) was added dropwise to the solution at −80 °C. The addition was completed in ca. 15 min. The mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h, after which P­(p-Tol)2Cl (4.4 mL, 20 mmol) was added dropwise at −80 °C and the solution became cloudy. The mixture was gradually brought to room temperature and stirred for 14 h to form a clouded yellow solution. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvent was concentrated and dissolved in dichloromethane (40 mL) in a flask. The solution was cooled to 0 °C, and 30% H2O2 aqueous solution (8.0 mL) was added to it. The reaction mixture was stirred for 3 h. The product was extracted with dichloromethane and the obtained crude powder was washed with ethyl acetate for several times to afford a white powder. Yield: 3.0 g (61%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD, 25 °C) δ 7.44–7.49 (m, 8H, −CH), δ 7.31–7.33 (m, 8H, −CH), δ 7.17 (t, 2H, −CH), δ 2.41 (s, 12H, −CH3) ppm. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C32H31O3P2 [M + H]+, 525.17; found, 525.17. Anal. Calcd for C32H30O3P2: C, 73.27; H, 5.77%. Found: C, 72.80; H, 5.66%.

Preparation of [Eu­(hfa)<sub>3</sub>(Cy)]<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic>

Phosphine oxide ligand Cy (0.80 mmol) and Eu­(hfa)3(H2O)2 (0.80 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (60 mL), respectively. The solutions were mixed and refluxed for 3 h to form white precipitates. The obtained white solid was washed with methanol. Yield: 0.54 g (53% for monomer). IR (KBr): 2854–2931 (m, C–H), 1656 (st, CO), 1139 (st, PO) cm–1. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C38H48EuF12O7P2 [M – hfa]+: 1059.2, found, 1059.3. Anal. Calcd for C43H49EuF18O9P2: C, 40.80; H, 3.90%. Found: C, 40.84; H, 3.84%.

Preparation of [Ln­(hfa)<sub>3</sub>(Tol)]<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (Ln = Eu, Tb, or Mixture Thereof)

Phosphine oxide ligand Tol (0.80 mmol) and Ln­(hfa)3(H2O)2 (0.80 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (60 mL), respectively. The solutions were mixed and refluxed for 3 h. The reaction mixture was concentrated and washed with chloroform. The solvent was evaporated and redissolved in 50 °C methanol for recrystallization. The obtained crystals were washed with −20 °C methanol.

[Eu­(hfa)<sub>3</sub>(Tol)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>

Yield: 0.66 g (64% for monomer). IR (KBr): 1650 (st, CO), 1133 (st, PO) cm–1. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C42H32EuF12O7P2 [M – hfa]+: 1091.06, found, 1091.07. Anal. Calcd for C47H33EuF18O9P2: C, 43.50; H, 2.56%. Found: C, 43.41; H, 2.42%.

[Tb­(hfa)<sub>3</sub>(Tol)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>

Yield: 0.56 g (54% for monomer). IR (KBr): 1650 (st, CO), 1133 (st, PO) cm–1. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C42H32F12O7P2Tb [M – hfa]+: 1097.07, found, 1097.03. Anal. Calcd for C47H33F18O9P2Tb: C, 43.27; H, 2.55%. Found: C, 43.18; H, 2.39%.

[Ln­(hfa)<sub>3</sub>(Tol)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (Tb/Eu = 1)

Yield: 0.58 g (56% for monomer). IR (KBr): 1650 (st, CO), 1133 (st, PO) cm–1. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C42H32EuF12O7P2 [M – hfa]+: 1091.06, C42H32F12O7P2Tb [M – hfa]+: 1097.07, found, 1091.02, 1097.03. Anal. Calcd for C47H33Eu0.5F18O9P2Tb0.5: C, 43.39; H, 2.56%. Found: C, 43.30; H, 2.34%.

[Ln­(hfa)<sub>3</sub>(Tol)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (Tb/Eu = 10)

Yield: 0.57 g (55% for monomer). IR (KBr): 1650 (st, CO), 1133 (st, PO) cm–1. ESI-Mass (m/z): calcd for C42H32EuF12O7P2 [M – hfa]+: 1091.06, C42H32F12O7P2Tb [M – hfa]+: 1097.07, found, 1091.02, 1097.02. Anal. Calcd for C47H33Eu0.09F18O9P2Tb0.91: C, 43.29; H, 2.55%. Found: C, 43.23; H, 2.39%.

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were also conducted to examine the thermodynamic stability of polymer chains. The decomposition points were estimated to be 334, 320, and 267 °C for [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n , [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n , and [Eu­(hfa)3(Ph)] n , respectively (). The remarkably high thermal stability of [Eu­(hfa)3(Cy)] n is due to the strong interactions through multiple intra- and intermolecular CH–F hydrogen bonds. The intramolecular CH–F and CH−π interactions in [Eu­(hfa)3(Tol)] n also allowed the polymer chains to be stable at temperatures above 300 °C, which was similar to the thermally stable helical EuIII coordination polymer with multiple intramolecular hydrogen bonds.
